description:
## Purpose and Context
This layer explores the relationship between mobility patterns, particulate matter concentrations, and population health risk at the level of Local Administrative Units (LAU).
By combining HFLB-based mobility indicators with modeled air quality data and a composite health risk index, the layer supports an exploratory assessment of potential associations between traffic-related mobility, particulate pollution, and short-term health impacts.

## Data Basis
The analysis integrates three groups of indicators:
1) Mobility Indicators (HFLB-based)
- Speed
- Motorized Share
- Motorized Count
- Trajectories (max)
- Trajectories (scaled)

2) Particulate Matter Concentrations 
Daily mass concentrations of PM2.5 and PM10 obtained from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) European air quality forecasts dataset.

3) Aggregate Health Risk Index (HRI)
A composite indicator representing the short-term health risk from simultaneous exposure to multiple air pollutants (PM10, PM2.5, NO2, SO2, and O3).
The index is calculated by additively summing pollutant concentrations weighted by health outcome-specific relative risk factors for all-cause mortality, as provided by the World Health Organization (WHO).

## Spatial Aggregation
All indicators are aggregated to the Local Administrative Unit (LAU) level.
This aggregation enables linkage between mobility, air quality, and population exposure, supports region-based comparison and interpretation, and reduces local-scale variability in modeled air quality data.

## Visualization and Interaction
The map displays PM2.5, PM10 concentrations, the Aggregate Health Risk Index (HRI), and selected mobility indicators at LAU level.

When selecting a LAU, scatter plots are generated showing the correlation between mobility indicators and air quality metrics. This allows users to compare the relative influence of different mobility metrics, explore spatial variability across administrative units, and to identify patterns, outliers, and non-linear relationships.

## Interpretation and Limitations
The displayed relationships reflect statistical associations rather than direct causal effects.
Particulate matter concentrations and health risk indicators are influenced by multiple factors, including meteorological conditions, regional background pollution, long-range transport of pollutants, and non-traffic-related emission sources.

The Aggregate Health Risk Index represents a modeled, population-level risk indicator and should not be interpreted as an observed health outcome.
